importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest update in the ongoing South Korean repatriation and investigation into its nationals involved in cyber scams in Cambodia.
This date corresponds to the repatriation of 64 South Korean nationals from Cambodia, indicating active and current international cooperation in combating cybercrime.
South Korea's recent ban on travel to certain areas of Cambodia, announced on this date, reflects a direct policy response to the growing threat of scam operations targeting its citizens.
The date coincides with the announcement of joint investigations into the death of a South Korean student in Cambodia, highlighting human rights and national security concerns.
The date when the South Korean student was found dead in Cambodia indicates the timeline of abuse and torture within scam centres, underscoring the severity of the issue.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2023 to 2025 reflects the escalation of online scam operations in Cambodia and the resulting international response, including travel bans and cross-border arrests.
The post-COVID-19 period (2020–2025) saw a surge in online scam activity, especially in Cambodia, as businesses pivoted to illicit operations during global shutdowns.

keyTakeAways: Dozens of South Korean nationals, including both voluntary and involuntary participants, were detained in Cambodia for involvement in online scam operations and have been repatriated and arrested.

The South Korean government has taken measures including banning travel to certain areas in Cambodia and launching a joint investigation into the death of a student allegedly tortured in a scam centre.
Cambodia's scam industry, especially in industrial-scale 'pig-butchering' operations, has become a global cybercrime hub, with operations linked to wealthy and politically connected figures.
The Prince Group, a Cambodia-based multinational crime network led by Chinese-Cambodian tycoon Chen Zhi, is under U.S. and U.K. sanctions for running scam centres generating up to $30 million daily.
Chen Zhi, an adviser to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet and former Prime Minister Hun Sen, is wanted for wire fraud and money laundering and faces up to 40 years in prison.
An estimated 200,000 people work in scam operations across Cambodia, with about 1,000 South Korean nationals believed to be among them.

Online romance scams, known as 'pig-butchering', build trust through fraudulent investment schemes before stealing funds, often targeting Western victims and resulting in billions of dollars in losses annually.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Dozens of South Korean nationals were detained in Cambodia for involvement in cyber scam operations, particularly in the 'pig-butchering' scam model involving fraudulent cryptocurrency investment schemes. They were repatriated via a chartered flight and placed under arrest. The South Korean government has responded with travel bans to parts of Cambodia and launched a joint investigation into the death of a student found tortured in Kampot province. International agencies, including the U.S. and U.K., have targeted the Prince Group, a Cambodia-based crime network led by Chinese-Cambodian tycoon Chen Zhi, who is linked to political figures including Hun Manet and Hun Sen. The operations have grown significantly since the pandemic, with thousands of workers, including around 1,000 South Koreans, reportedly involved. The article highlights the severe human rights violations and the global scale of cybercrime in Southeast Asia.
title: Dozens of South Koreans freed from Cambodia scam centres now home, arrested
